content: Thank you to all for the approval !

Maybe because it's late, but I think that this CoC can be really hard for some people, especially if they are beginners or/and want to do as I did but in C/Java.

Nevertheless, I won't reject it because some CoCs shouldn't be easy !

Have a good night :)

import sys
text = input()
print(text,file=sys.stderr)

little_text=""
r=0
for i in range(1,len(text)+1):
    little_text = text[:i]
    print(little_text,file=sys.stderr)

    is_good = True
    for j in range(i,len(text)-i+1,i):
        query = text[j:j+i]

        if not query == little_text:
            is_good = False
            break
    if not is_good:continue
    r = len(text)%i
    if r==0:print("{}*{}".format(little_text,len(text)//i));exit()
    elif text[-r:] == little_text[:r]:
        print("{}*({}+{}/{})".format(little_text,len(text)//i,r,len(little_text)))
        exit()
for me is not to hard.

Maybe, it depends on the language.

It took me about 5 minutes to write the solution in Python3. (But maybe it was easy for me because I was already thinking about it while writing the statement).

Also, I'm not a java expert, but it looks like your code could be simplified.
You compare the string part by part (with the "goodSoFar" boolean). But you could build a test string from the variable "phrase", then compare it to the reference string in one time.

And "len==len2" implies "len%len2==0", so, one of the condition could be simplified as " if(len%len2==0) ".
In most cases, Python3 is a lot more concise than Java and more suitable for CoC.
I don't disagree, I've just always been a Java guy. Like I said, it could've just been me, so that's why i worded my comment as such.

Also for CoC, performance is often not the primary concern. So sometimes you could apply inefficient but easier-to-implement approaches as long as the upper bound of input size is not high. For example, in this problem, you can use String::repeat (available in Java 11) to repeat the each candidate word appropriate number of times, and then check whether it starts with the input string.
